Where to start

There are some basic features that you need to override before you go public. This is the only time youâ€™ll see the code, I promise.

Title

The first thing you need to do is change the name of the site from â€œLilium Digital Gardenâ€ to the actual name of your digital garden.

To do so, you have to open the file named â€œ_config.ymlâ€ whit a text editor. On the very first line youâ€™ll find the name of the site, you just change that and save the file. Then youâ€™ll prbably need to serve the site again, as I explained here (if youâ€™re running it locally this means stop it and then run â€œbundle ecex jekyll serveâ€ again, then reload the page).

Top navigation

Top navigation is the simple menu you see above the title. There you can add more pages, but for now, I suggest you to just delete the â€œDocumentâ€ and the â€œDownload Liliumâ€ links.

To do so, you have to open the â€œ_includesâ€ folder, and then open the â€œnav.htmlâ€ with a text editor. Youâ€™ll find a list of four links, all you have to do is delete these last two and save the document.

About page

One more thing youâ€™ll obviously edit is the â€œAboutâ€ page. There you can add your personal information, such as bio, contacts and so on. Down on this page youâ€™ll find some tips on how to write on a Jekyll page (such as sintax etc).

Remember that the content of the â€œAboutâ€ page is written inside the â€œabout.mdâ€ document in the â€œ_pagesâ€ folder. âš ï¸ Make sure you edit this document and NOT the â€œabout.htmlâ€ document in the â€œ_layoutsâ€ folder.

Floating elements

The floating elements are:

  1. the â€œAbout meâ€ block you se on right bottom corner of the pages,
  2. the social icons on the â€œAboutâ€ pages.

These, of course, contains more personal informations. To edit them youâ€™ll have to edit the â€œfloating-about.htmlâ€ document and the â€œfloating-social.htmlâ€ document inside the â€œ_includesâ€ folder.

For the floating about, you just replace the text between the â€œ<p>â€ tag and the â€œ</p>â€ tag with your own text.

For the social icons, youâ€™ll just replace my social urls with yours. I provided some other icons that are not displayed (such as LinkedIn, YouTube, Pinterest, Reddit and Twitch) inside the â€œassets/iconsâ€ folder. To replace them youâ€™ll just have to type the name of the social in this space.

Or you can add or remove icons by duplicate or delete a whole block contained between the â€œ<li>â€ and the â€œ</li>â€.

Useful Tips

Now youâ€™re free to do whatever you want with your digital garden. But before my job is done, let me give you just a couple of tips that will probably make you spare some time.

Jekyll is an amazing tool, but there are some basic rules that youâ€™ll learn soon. One of them is the language. In Jekyll we write in a language called markdown language, and thatâ€™s why your notes are stored in files that have the â€œ.mdâ€ extention.

Markdown is pretty easy to learn, itâ€™s just a combination of symbols actually, like â€œ#â€ for titles, single â€œ*â€ for italic and double for bold, and so on. Anyway, il could be useful to start to take a look at a guide.

To make it even easyer, I suggest you to download a proper text editor, like Atom or Visual Studio, that can help you with syntax mistakes. When youâ€™ll be ready, youâ€™ll discover how many amazing things you can create by mixing markdown with some HTLM.

Another thing that you should probably know is that creative does not mean messy. Itâ€™s much easier use a Jekyll site if its directories are in order. So, when you create a new note, you should put it in the â€œ_notesâ€ folder. This way, it will apprear in the â€œSeedsâ€ section, which is a blog-style list of your entries. Here you can find a lot of information on that page, such as how to change the order of the displayed notes. In any case, I suggest you to take a look at the Jekyll documentation.
